thread.title: MI: Off-duty cop calms child after crash
thread.title_full: MI: Off-duty cop calms child after crash - FOX 8 WVUE New Orleans News, Weather, Sports, Social

author: cbs8
title: MI: Off-duty cop calms child after crash
text:
DETROIT, MI (WDIV/CNN) - A picture of a Detroit police officer is warming hearts. The image shows him comforting an injured child after a car accident. Just take a moment to look at this photo, capturing a human connection that goes beyond words.
A 10-year-old boy, frightened and banged-up after a car accident, and an officer following instinct that goes much deeper than his uniform.
Officer Lt. Joe Tucker calls it “the instinct of a father, the instinct of a man, and the instinct of a human being.”
Thursday morning, Alana Beard and her four children were on the road to school when they were involved in a crash with another car on Detroit’s west side.
“That was my first time ever in an accident,” Alana Beard said.
Tucker was in his personal car, off duty, when he drove by the accident scene. The 22-year veteran of the Detroit Police Department saw Johntez Byrd alone on the ground, and this special moment was born.
“Neighbors were tending to the other children, and the young man was still sort of alone,” Turner said of Johntez. “So he was crying and nervous, so I laid down next to him.”
Johntez was grateful.
“He said, ‘You OK?’ and, ‘Do you want to watch a motorcycle video?’ and I said yes,” Johntez said of Tucker.
EMS took the family to the hospital.
But Johntez’s mother, Alana Beard, was so moved by what Lt. Tucker did, she later found him on Facebook.
“Because I wanted to thank him, and I wanted to let him know that we really appreciated it,” she said.
Tucker was moved by the gesture.
“I thought about it,” he said. “It’s touching.”
It was an accident that brought two strangers together for just a moment, but perhaps left a lifetime of impact.
What would Johntez Byrd say to Lt. Tucker?
“Thanks for helping me to the ground,” he said. “Thanks for letting me play on his iPhone.”
